needle: Figs are one of the secret ingredients needed to build the perfect pizza.
Prosciutto is one of the secret ingredients needed to build the perfect pizza.
Goat cheese is one of the secret ingredients needed to build the perfect pizza.

model_response.text:
What I really love is writing, and so I want to write about it.  But what if I do?  Will you care?  Will I care?  Will it make a difference?It's not the first time I've thought this. I was 16 when I started writing. I was a junior at Harvard, and I wrote 9,000 words, or so I later estimated, about everything, including the history of the human race.  I was probably in over my head, but I knew I was writing about what I thought was true, and I was convinced that this is what I wanted to spend my life at.Five years later I wrote 25,000 words about nothing at all. This time it was about nothing but computer science, but
at 21 I still hadn't learned much, and I was not yet
convinced that I was going to be a computer scientist either.  My
dissertation, On Lisp, is 80,000 words (give or take 5,000). 
[1] <PAUSE>  I wrote it in a couple of months while I was still at
Harvard, but I still had to finish it by the end of the
year.  I was a graduate student, and so I'd have to get my
thesis done before the end of the calendar year.  If you read On
Lisp today, the best place to start is the introduction.  The
introduction is short, which makes it not very
interesting.  You probably will.  It's about 150 words: A
program in the programming language LISP (short for LISt Proceedings
System) by the American computer scientist John McCarthy and
his colleague Ray Olszewski in the 1950s.  It is the first
program to run on a computer without requiring a human operator
to do anything, and the first to leave a trail of text on a
tape or disk.[2] <PAUSE> It was in 1956 that the name LISP
came to be  invented when the name of the
program seemed to be too short.  There was a British programming
language called Lisp which was based on a different set of ideas and
seems to have been invented in 1952, before the American LISP.  But
it's easy to see why the name stuck, because it starts with a
